title: Psalms Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 2.

questions.question: According to Psalms 2:1, why do the heathen rage?
options: Because they love the Lord
Because the people imagine a vain thing
Because they seek peace
Because they worship idols
questions.correctAnswer: Because the people imagine a vain thing
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:1 says, 'Why do the heathen rage, and the people imagine a vain thing?' showing that their rage is due to vain imaginations.

questions.question: Who do the kings and rulers take counsel against according to Psalms 2:2?
options: The LORD and his anointed
The people of the earth
The priests and Levites
The prophets
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD and his anointed
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:2 states that the kings of the earth and rulers take counsel together against the LORD and his anointed.

questions.question: What do the kings say they will do in Psalms 2:3?
options: Let us break their bands asunder
Let us worship the LORD
Let us build a temple
Let us seek peace
questions.correctAnswer: Let us break their bands asunder
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:3 says the kings say, 'Let us break their bands asunder, and cast away their cords from us.'

questions.question: What is the Lord's reaction to the rebellion of the kings and people in Psalms 2:4?
options: He shall cry out
He shall weep
He shall laugh
He shall hide
questions.correctAnswer: He shall laugh
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:4 states, 'He that sitteth in the heavens shall laugh: the Lord shall have them in derision.'

questions.question: Where has the LORD set His king according to Psalms 2:6?
options: On the holy hill of Zion
In the wilderness
In the temple
By the rivers of Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: On the holy hill of Zion
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:6 says, 'Yet have I set my king upon my holy hill of Zion.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 2:7, what title does the LORD give to His king?
options: My Prophet
My Son
My Servant
My Judge
questions.correctAnswer: My Son
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:7 says, 'Thou art my Son; this day have I begotten thee.'

questions.question: What does the LORD promise to give to His king in Psalms 2:8?
options: The heathen for an inheritance
A crown of gold
A throne in Jerusalem
The laws of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: The heathen for an inheritance
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:8 states, 'Ask of me, and I shall give thee the heathen for thine inheritance, and the uttermost parts of the earth for thy possession.'

questions.question: How will the king rule the nations according to Psalms 2:9?
options: With a rod of iron
With kindness and mercy
With a sword of fire
With gentle words
questions.correctAnswer: With a rod of iron
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:9 says, 'Thou shalt break them with a rod of iron; thou shalt dash them in pieces like a potter's vessel.'

questions.question: What advice is given to kings and judges in Psalms 2:10?
options: Be wise now therefore
Be strong and courageous
Seek peace at all times
Ignore the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Be wise now therefore
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:10 instructs, 'Be wise now therefore, O ye kings: be instructed, ye judges of the earth.'

questions.question: What are the people instructed to do in Psalms 2:11?
options: Serve the LORD with fear and rejoice with trembling
Offer sacrifices daily
Pray without ceasing
Build altars to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Serve the LORD with fear and rejoice with trembling
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:11 says, 'Serve the LORD with fear, and rejoice with trembling.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 2:4 says the Lord will weep at the rebellion of the heathen.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:4 states that the Lord shall laugh and have them in derision, not weep.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 2:7 declares the king as the Son of the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:7 clearly states, 'Thou art my Son; this day have I begotten thee.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 2:12 says that those who put their trust in the Son are blessed.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:12 concludes with 'Blessed are all they that put their trust in him.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 2:3: 'Let us break their ______ asunder.'
options: bands
walls
chains
shields
questions.correctAnswer: bands
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:3 says, 'Let us break their bands asunder, and cast away their cords from us.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 2:12: 'Kiss the Son, lest he be _______, and ye perish from the way.'
options: angry
pleased
silent
forgotten
questions.correctAnswer: angry
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:12 says, 'Kiss the Son, lest he be angry, and ye perish from the way.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 2, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God during opposition?
options: God laughs at the opposition and controls the outcome
We should avoid conflict at all costs
Human rulers have ultimate power over God's plans
We must rely on our own strength to overcome
questions.correctAnswer: God laughs at the opposition and controls the outcome
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:1-4 teach that although the nations rage and plot against God, He who sits in heaven laughs and holds them in derision, showing His sovereign control even in opposition.

questions.question: How does Psalms 2 instruct believers to respond to God's Son in humility and reverence?
options: Serve the LORD with fear and rejoice with trembling
Ignore His commands and follow our own path
Demand signs before believing
Avoid worship as a sign of independence
questions.correctAnswer: Serve the LORD with fear and rejoice with trembling
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:11 commands believers to serve God with reverence and to rejoice with trembling, highlighting the proper attitude toward God's authority.

questions.question: What practical advice does Psalms 2 give to leaders about dealing with rebellion and opposition?
options: Be wise and take instruction to avoid God's wrath
Push harder against God’s commands
Ignore God's will and follow popular opinion
Rely solely on military power
questions.correctAnswer: Be wise and take instruction to avoid God's wrath
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:10 advises kings and judges to be wise and receive instruction to avoid angering God and perishing under His wrath.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with fear about God's discipline. What encouragement does Psalms 2 provide about God's wrath and blessing?
options: God's wrath is kindled only a little, and blessings come to those who trust Him
God is always angry and unforgiving
Trusting God guarantees no trials
God’s blessings depend on our strength
questions.correctAnswer: God's wrath is kindled only a little, and blessings come to those who trust Him
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:12 warns about God's anger but also promises blessing for those who trust in Him, encouraging believers to put their faith in God's mercy.

questions.question: How does Psalms 2 illustrate the importance of trusting God's sovereign plan in family leadership?
options: God has set His King on Zion, demonstrating His authority over all leadership
Family leaders should ignore God and rely on personal wisdom
Parents must depend on worldly power to lead
Leadership is based only on popularity
questions.correctAnswer: God has set His King on Zion, demonstrating His authority over all leadership
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:6 shows God's appointment of His King on Zion, which reflects His ultimate authority that family and community leaders should submit to.

questions.question: What does Psalms 2 teach about the inheritance and authority given to God's Son, and how does that impact Christian work ethic?
options: The Son is given the nations as inheritance, encouraging believers to work as His representatives
Believers should avoid responsibility in the world
Work is unimportant in God's kingdom
Authority is based on earthly power alone
questions.correctAnswer: The Son is given the nations as inheritance, encouraging believers to work as His representatives
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:8 states God gives the nations to His Son, implying believers should engage in their work with the responsibility of representing God's reign.

questions.question: According to Psalms 2, what is the consequence of rejecting God's anointed, and how should this shape Christian attitudes toward temptation?
options: Rejection leads to wrath and destruction, so believers must persevere and trust God
There are no consequences for rejecting God
Temptation is a sign to give up faith
God’s wrath is irrelevant to daily life
questions.correctAnswer: Rejection leads to wrath and destruction, so believers must persevere and trust God
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:5 and 2:12 warn of God's wrath against those who reject His Son, encouraging believers to remain steadfast and trust in Him during trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 2 guide believers in their prayer life when facing opposition?
options: Ask God for help, trusting He will grant victory
Avoid praying about difficult situations
Depend on human wisdom alone
Pray only when everything is going well
questions.correctAnswer: Ask God for help, trusting He will grant victory
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:8 encourages asking God for the nations as an inheritance, symbolizing reliance on His power in prayer for overcoming opposition.

questions.question: What does Psalms 2 teach about humility and recognizing God's authority in church fellowship?
options: Kiss the Son to show submission and avoid His anger
Ignore God’s authority in group decisions
Push personal agendas over God’s Word
Avoid fellowship to prevent conflict
questions.correctAnswer: Kiss the Son to show submission and avoid His anger
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:12 calls for reverence and submission to God's Son as a way to receive blessing and avoid wrath, foundational for unity in the church.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 2 teaches that God's appointed King will use a rod of iron to break rebellious peoples.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:9 states the King will break them with a rod of iron and dash them like a potter's vessel, symbolizing divine authority and judgment.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 2 encourages believers to rejoice with trembling when serving the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:11 instructs believers to serve the LORD with fear and rejoice with trembling, reflecting reverence combined with joy.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Psalms 2:7, the LORD said, 'Thou art my _____; this day have I begotten thee.'
options: Son
King
Servant
Prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Son
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:7 explicitly states that the LORD declares, 'Thou art my Son,' affirming the divine sonship of the anointed King.

questions.question: How does Psalms 2 teach us about integrity and honesty in leadership roles?
options: Leaders should seek God’s wisdom and instruction to rule justly
Deceit is acceptable if it secures power
Leaders must only please the people
Ignoring God leads to better leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders should seek God’s wisdom and instruction to rule justly
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:10 encourages rulers to be wise and take instruction, implying that integrity and reliance on God's guidance are essential for just leadership.

questions.question: What biblical principle about perseverance through trials can be drawn from Psalms 2?
options: Trusting in God brings blessing despite opposition
Trials mean God has abandoned us
We should give up when faced with rebellion
Only physical strength matters in trials
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting in God brings blessing despite opposition
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:12 highlights that those who put their trust in God are blessed, encouraging perseverance and faith through difficult times.

questions.question: According to Psalms 2, how should believers view earthly rulers who oppose God’s anointed?
options: They are ultimately under God's judgment and will be broken
They have ultimate authority over believers
Their plans cannot be thwarted
Believers should fear them above God
questions.correctAnswer: They are ultimately under God's judgment and will be broken
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:3,9 shows that those who rebel against God's anointed will be broken like pottery, demonstrating God's sovereign judgment over earthly rulers.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 2.

questions.question: What is the primary reason given in Psalms 2:1 for the raging of the heathen and the vain imaginations of the people?
options: They oppose the LORD and His anointed
They seek to establish their own kingdoms
They desire wealth and power
They are deceived by false prophets
questions.correctAnswer: They oppose the LORD and His anointed
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:1 asks why the heathen rage and the people imagine vain things, which contextually is because they oppose the LORD and His anointed as explained in verse 2.

questions.question: According to Psalms 2:2, who take counsel together against the LORD and His anointed?
options: The kings of the earth and the rulers
The priests and the prophets
The Levites and the scribes
The elders and the judges
questions.correctAnswer: The kings of the earth and the rulers
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:2 explicitly states that the kings of the earth and the rulers take counsel together against the LORD and His anointed.

questions.question: In Psalms 2:3, what do the conspirators desire to break asunder and cast away?
options: Their bands and cords
The walls of Jerusalem
The covenant and promises
The altars and sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: Their bands and cords
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:3 describes the rebellious desire to break their bands asunder and cast away their cords, symbolizing rejection of God's rule.

questions.question: What is the response of the One who sits in the heavens to the rebellion described in Psalms 2:4?
options: He laughs and holds them in derision
He immediately punishes them
He sends prophets to warn them
He hides His face from them
questions.correctAnswer: He laughs and holds them in derision
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:4 states that He who sits in the heavens laughs and has them in derision, indicating divine sovereignty and contempt for their rebellion.

questions.question: Which phrase best describes God's reaction in Psalms 2:5 after His initial laughter at the rebellious kings?
options: He speaks in wrath and vexes them
He forgives and shows mercy
He remains silent and distant
He rejoices in their humility
questions.correctAnswer: He speaks in wrath and vexes them
questions.explanation: According to Psalms 2:5, after laughing, God speaks in wrath and vexes the rebellious kings in His sore displeasure.

questions.question: Where has God set His king according to Psalms 2:6, and what is the significance of this location in ancient Israelite worship?
options: On the holy hill of Zion, the center of worship and God's dwelling
On Mount Sinai, where the law was given
In Babylon, symbolizing captivity
In the Valley of Jezreel, a battlefield
questions.correctAnswer: On the holy hill of Zion, the center of worship and God's dwelling
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:6 states the king is set upon the holy hill of Zion, significant as the spiritual and political center where God’s presence dwelled.

questions.question: In Psalms 2:7, what declaration is made by the LORD about His Son, and how does this verse serve as a messianic prophecy?
options: Thou art my Son; this day have I begotten thee
Thou shalt reign forever without end
Thy throne shall be established in righteousness
Thou shalt bring peace to the nations
questions.correctAnswer: Thou art my Son; this day have I begotten thee
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:7 declares the LORD calling the king His Son, a foundational messianic prophecy referenced in the New Testament regarding Christ's divine sonship.

questions.question: According to Psalms 2:8, what is promised to the Son upon asking, and what does this signify in a broader biblical context?
options: The heathen for inheritance and the ends of the earth for possession
A throne above all earthly kingdoms
A crown of righteousness from the LORD
Peace among all nations
questions.correctAnswer: The heathen for inheritance and the ends of the earth for possession
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:8 promises the Son the heathen and the uttermost parts of the earth, indicating universal dominion, a theme echoed in Daniel 7 and Revelation.

questions.question: What metaphor is used in Psalms 2:9 to describe the authority and power of the Son over the nations?
options: Breaking them with a rod of iron and dashing them like a potter's vessel
Wielding a sword of fire
Riding a white horse
Pouring out wrath like a storm
questions.correctAnswer: Breaking them with a rod of iron and dashing them like a potter's vessel
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:9 uses the rod of iron and potter's vessel imagery to portray the Son’s absolute power to rule and judge the nations.

questions.question: Psalms 2:10 advises kings and judges of the earth to be wise. How does this counsel relate to the theme of divine sovereignty in the chapter?
options: It urges submission to God's anointed to avoid judgment
It encourages rebellion against unjust rulers
It calls for political alliances among nations
It demands strict adherence to human laws
questions.correctAnswer: It urges submission to God's anointed to avoid judgment
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:10 calls for wisdom and instruction, implying that earthly rulers should submit to God's anointed to avoid His wrath, reinforcing divine sovereignty.

questions.question: What paradoxical attitude toward serving the LORD is expressed in Psalms 2:11?
options: Serve the LORD with fear, and rejoice with trembling
Serve the LORD with joy and laughter
Serve the LORD without fear or trembling
Serve the LORD with strict ritual only
questions.correctAnswer: Serve the LORD with fear, and rejoice with trembling
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:11 combines reverent fear with joyful trembling, emphasizing a complex response to God's authority.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 2:12: 'Kiss the ______, lest he be angry, and ye perish from the way.'
options: Son
Lord
King
Prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Son
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:12 commands to 'Kiss the Son,' a gesture of homage and submission to avoid wrath.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 2 portrays the rebellion of earthly rulers as ultimately successful in overthrowing God's anointed.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 2 depicts the rebellion as futile, with God laughing and ultimately establishing His king on Zion, showing divine victory (Psalms 2:4-6).

questions.question: How does the use of the phrase 'this day have I begotten thee' in Psalms 2:7 relate to New Testament Christology?
options: It is quoted in Acts as evidence of Jesus' resurrection and divine sonship
It refers exclusively to King David’s coronation
It foretells the coming of the Holy Spirit at Pentecost
It describes the creation of angels
questions.correctAnswer: It is quoted in Acts as evidence of Jesus' resurrection and divine sonship
questions.explanation: Acts 13:33 quotes Psalms 2:7 to affirm Jesus as the begotten Son of God, connecting the Psalm to New Testament theology.

questions.question: Considering the historical context, who were likely the 'kings of the earth' referenced in Psalms 2:2, and what was their relationship to Israel?
options: Foreign rulers opposing Israel's God and messianic king
Israelite tribal chiefs uniting under David
Priestly leaders within the temple
The judges of Israel during the wilderness period
questions.correctAnswer: Foreign rulers opposing Israel's God and messianic king
questions.explanation: The 'kings of the earth' in Psalms 2:2 likely refer to pagan rulers who opposed Israel's God and His anointed king, reflecting geopolitical tensions in the ancient Near East.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 2:1, what motivates the heathen and peoples to rage and imagine vain things?
options: They oppose God's anointed
They seek to establish peace
They desire wisdom and understanding
They long for the Messiah
questions.correctAnswer: They oppose God's anointed
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:1 states that the heathen rage and the people imagine vain things, which is understood as opposition against God's anointed. This theme is echoed in Acts 4:25-26 where the nations rage against the Lord and His Christ, and in Revelation 11:18 where nations are angry but God's wrath is revealed.

questions.question: In Psalms 2:2, who are described as taking counsel together against the LORD and His Anointed?
options: The kings of the earth and the rulers
The priests and prophets
The people of Israel and Judah
The angels and heavenly hosts
questions.correctAnswer: The kings of the earth and the rulers
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:2 clearly identifies the kings and rulers of the earth as conspiring against the LORD and His Anointed. This opposition is also addressed in Daniel 7:25 and Revelation 17:14 where earthly powers oppose God's kingdom and Christ the King.

questions.question: What is the response of the One who sits in the heavens to the rebellion described in Psalms 2:3-4?
options: He laughs and mocks them
He immediately destroys them
He pleads for their repentance
He remains silent
questions.correctAnswer: He laughs and mocks them
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:4 states that the One sitting in the heavens laughs and holds them in derision. This divine response shows God's supreme authority and sovereignty, as also reflected in Job 41:24 and Isaiah 37:23 where God mocks the proud and haughty.

questions.question: According to Psalms 2:6, where has the LORD set His king?
options: Upon the holy hill of Zion
In the courts of heaven
On the throne of David
In the garden of Eden
questions.correctAnswer: Upon the holy hill of Zion
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:6 reveals that the LORD has set His king upon the holy hill of Zion, symbolizing God's chosen place for His reign. This location is significant in 2 Samuel 5:7 and Isaiah 24:23 where Zion is the seat of God's kingdom.

questions.question: How does Psalms 2:7 describe the relationship between the LORD and His Son?
options: The LORD declares the Son as begotten this day
The Son is equal and co-eternal with the LORD
The Son is created before all things
The Son is a servant to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD declares the Son as begotten this day
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:7 states, 'Thou art my Son; this day have I begotten thee,' affirming the unique sonship and divine appointment of the Messiah. This is echoed in Hebrews 1:5 and Acts 13:33 where the resurrection confirms Jesus as the begotten Son of God.

questions.question: What promise is given in Psalms 2:8 to the Son regarding the nations?
options: The heathen shall be His inheritance and the ends of the earth His possession
The Son will judge the nations by fire
The nations will worship the Son in Jerusalem
The Son will establish a temporal kingdom over Israel alone
questions.correctAnswer: The heathen shall be His inheritance and the ends of the earth His possession
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:8 promises that the Son will receive the nations as an inheritance and the ends of the earth as a possession, highlighting the universal reign of Christ. This is supported by Matthew 28:18 and Revelation 11:15 where Christ's kingdom extends over all nations.

questions.question: According to Psalms 2:9, what authority does the Son have over the nations?
options: To break them with a rod of iron and dash them like a potter's vessel
To bind them with chains of gold
To govern them with mercy and grace
To lead them in peaceful counsel
questions.correctAnswer: To break them with a rod of iron and dash them like a potter's vessel
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:9 depicts the Son's authority to rule with unyielding power, breaking rebellious nations like a potter’s vessel. This imagery is reiterated in Revelation 2:27 and 19:15, emphasizing Christ’s sovereign judgment.

questions.question: In Psalms 2:10, what admonition is given to earthly rulers?
options: Be wise and be instructed
Increase your armies and fortify your cities
Seek alliances with other nations
Ignore the LORD and His decrees
questions.correctAnswer: Be wise and be instructed
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:10 urges kings and judges to be wise and receive instruction, recognizing the authority of God’s Anointed. Proverbs 2:6 and Ecclesiastes 8:2 similarly call for wisdom and reverence before God’s sovereignty.

questions.question: What attitude does Psalms 2:11 recommend toward the LORD?
options: Serve the LORD with fear and rejoice with trembling
Serve the LORD with joyful noise and praise
Serve the LORD without fear but with confidence
Serve the LORD only when commanded
questions.correctAnswer: Serve the LORD with fear and rejoice with trembling
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:11 calls for reverent service to the LORD coupled with a trembling joy, highlighting the balance of fear and gladness in worship. This mirrors Ecclesiastes 12:13 and Philippians 2:12 where believers are urged to work out their salvation with fear and trembling.

questions.question: What is the consequence mentioned in Psalms 2:12 for those who do not 'kiss the Son'?
options: They will perish when His wrath is kindled
They will be exalted by God
They will receive forgiveness
They will be granted peace
questions.correctAnswer: They will perish when His wrath is kindled
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:12 warns that failing to honor the Son results in perishing under His wrath. This theme is also found in John 3:36 and Romans 1:18 where rejection of Christ brings judgment.

questions.question: How does Psalms 2:7 relate to New Testament Christology?
options: It is cited as proof of Christ's divine sonship and resurrection
It refers only to King David's earthly reign
It describes a symbolic sonship of Israel
It is used to describe an angelic figure
questions.correctAnswer: It is cited as proof of Christ's divine sonship and resurrection
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:7 is quoted in Hebrews 1:5 and Acts 13:33 to affirm Jesus as the begotten Son of God, particularly in relation to His resurrection and divine authority, emphasizing His unique sonship and messianic role.

questions.question: What theological truth about God's sovereignty is illustrated in Psalms 2:4-5?
options: God laughs at the rebellion and will execute His wrath
God tolerates rebellion indefinitely
God negotiates peace with rebels
God is unaware of earthly affairs
questions.correctAnswer: God laughs at the rebellion and will execute His wrath
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:4-5 depicts God's sovereign rule over rebellious nations, laughing at their futile opposition and promising to bring judgment. Similar themes appear in Isaiah 37:23 and Nahum 1:2, affirming God's ultimate control and righteous indignation.

questions.question: What eschatological hope is implied in Psalms 2:8-9?
options: The Messiah will inherit and rule all nations with power
The world will be destroyed without hope
The Messiah will reign only in Israel
The nations will rebel forever
questions.correctAnswer: The Messiah will inherit and rule all nations with power
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:8-9 prophesies the Messiah’s universal dominion and authoritative judgment, consistent with Revelation 11:15 and Daniel 7:14 where Christ’s kingdom is established over all nations in the end times.

questions.question: How does Psalms 2:12 describe the blessedness of those who trust in the Son?
options: They are blessed and will not perish under His wrath
They will never face trials
They will be wealthy and powerful
They are hidden from all affliction
questions.correctAnswer: They are blessed and will not perish under His wrath
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:12 pronounces blessing on all who put their trust in the Son, promising preservation from wrath. This blessing aligns with Romans 8:1 and John 3:18 where faith in Christ secures eternal life and deliverance from judgment.

questions.question: Which attribute of God is most clearly demonstrated in Psalms 2:5?
options: His wrath and justice against sinners
His mercy towards all nations
His indifference to human affairs
His silence in the face of rebellion
questions.correctAnswer: His wrath and justice against sinners
questions.explanation: Psalms 2:5 shows God's wrath and displeasure as He speaks to punish rebellious rulers. This attribute is consistent with Romans 1:18 and Nahum 1:2 where God's righteous anger is directed against sin and rebellion.
